description:
It also takes a long time to load up. Maybe there are some compatibility layers or something underneath it. It provides the basic functionality that you'd expect from a commercial cryptocurrency wallet. It allows you to set your own fees, and supports a good number of currencies including BCH, ETH, and USDC as well as good old BTC. It's non-custodial too, which is a plus.

The mobile version is pretty good, but they were lazy in porting it over and as such, the UI is really reminicent of a mobile phone. Good for phones, not so good for computers.

I cannot stress how "meh" this wallet is. It's fine enough and tolerable for most people, and for that, I guess it gets a recommendation.
summary: User interface isn't great, but otherwise acceptable

description: UI is nice, is well supported, new features are constantly being added.

I only store all my BTC in cold offline paper wallets, but once a while use this wallet to store some of my crypto and never had any issue. Payments were fast and I never lost anything despite making numerous payments here and there. I think people who lose money have infected machines and may be victims of phishing. I have a copy installed in my iPhone and now my Ubuntu box. Just remember the seed phrase and you'll be fine!

All OG bitcoiners know that BitPay is just PayPal wearing a bitcoin hat. They will lie to you, they will misrepresent their values, they will fail to deliver on promises. BTCPay Server was founded as an open source alternative to this horrific company and there's a thriving community which can support learning around that project.
